choices.text: Homogeneous thin greyish discharge
Amine odour after adding 10% KOH
Epithelial cells studded with coccobacilli.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of the criteria used for the diagnosis of Bacterial vaginosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vaginal PH < 4.5

 

Option B. Vaginal PH < 4.5

 

Explanation:

 

  • Amsel criteria is used for the diagnosis of Bacterial vaginosis.


 

 

  • An altered microflora in vagina with a decrease in lactobacilli and an increase in anaerobic organisms like Gardnerella vaginalis, Mycoplasma hominis, Ureaplasma, and Prevotella species are the causes of bacterial vaginosis.
  • The highly sensitive Nugent scoring system is regarded as the gold standard for bacterial vaginosis.
  • It is calculated by looking at the results of Gram-stained smears, the quantity of lactobacilli, and the anaerobes morphology. Bacterial vaginosis is indicated by high scores of 7 to 10.
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize that an elevated vaginal pH greater than 4.5, not less than 4.5, is a diagnostic criterion for Bacterial vaginosis, alongside a homogenous thin greyish discharge, a positive whiff test, and the presence of clue cells.

 

Ref: Journal https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4802101/ 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 112, Page no 112.23

Online Resource

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/bacterial-vaginosis-clinical-manifestations-and-diagnosis?search=amsel&sectionRank=1&usage_type=default&anchor=H110845310&source=machineLearning&selectedTitle=1~3&display_rank=1#H110845310

questions.text: A female comes with frothy, green vaginal discharge of 5 days duration. There was a strawberry cervix on examination. The drug of choice is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metronidazole

 

Option A:

Metronidazole
 

  • This is the description of vaginal discharge caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • It is transmitted by sexual intercourse, with an incubation period of 4-21 days.
  • It typically results in vaginal soreness, frequent urination, and a copious, frothy, yellow-green discharge in females with a pH > 4.5.
  • Males may have non-specific urethritis without any symptoms.
  • The presence of motile organisms on a wet film frequently makes a diagnosis in females simple to confirm.
  • Although it is not done frequently, culture in the Feinberg-Whittington medium is the most reliable method.
  • A 2g PO single dose of metronidazole is the standard of care. Patients should refrain from sexual activity for 7 days following the last dose of antibiotics, regardless of the course of treatment.
  • The below image shows colpitis macularis or strawberry cervix, which is a characteristic finding of trichomoniasis. It results from microscopic, punctate hemorrhages of the cervix.


 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tetracycline is not the treatment of choice for trichomoniasis; it is more commonly used for bacterial infections, including some sexually transmitted infections like chlamydia.

 

Option C. Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily to treat yeast infections, not protozoan infections like trichomoniasis.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic that is not effective against protozoan infections and is not indicated for the treatment of trichomoniasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient is present with frothy, green vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix, the most likely diagnosis is trichomoniasis.
  • The first-line treatment for this condition is Metronidazole.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 33, Page no’s 33.35 and 33.36

questions.text: A 26-year-old man complains of burning pain when urinating. He reluctantly acknowledges that four days ago, he engaged in unprotected sexual activity. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria Gonorrhoeae

 

Option D:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae
 

  • The patient's symptoms, which appeared four days after unprotected sex, are consistent with urethritis brought on by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, whose incubation period is one to five days.
  • Male gonococcal infection most frequently manifests as acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Depending on the nature of the sexual contact, pharyngeal and rectal infections can also happen.
     
  • However, the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may also be affected. In women, the cervix is the primary site of infection.
     
  • Excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, profound dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, and intermenstrual bleeding are among the symptoms.
     
  • Non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is most frequently brought on by Chlamydia, which has a 1–3-week incubation period.
    Typically, only dysuria is present, but mucopurulent discharge can also happen. NGU can also be brought on by Mycoplasma genitalium and Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chlamydia trachomatis:
 

  • It is also a common cause of urethritis, but it typically causes a less pronounced or even asymptomatic presentation compared to gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Mycoplasma genitalium:
 

  • It is another cause of urethritis but is less common than gonorrhea and chlamydia and often causes milder symptoms.

 

Option C. Trichomonas vaginalis:
 

  • This causes trichomoniasis which typically presents with a frothy discharge and is more commonly symptomatic in females than males.



Educational Objective:

 

  • When a male patient presents with purulent urethral discharge and reports recent unprotected sexual activity, the most likely diagnosis is gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Identification is typically confirmed through culture of the discharge.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 30, Page no 30.3

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition Page no 1005

Online Resource

https://www.uptodate.com/contents/urethritis-in-adult-men?search=mycoplasma%20genitalium&source=search_result&selectedTitle=3~31&usage_type=default&display_rank=3#H1458429

choices.text: Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM + Azithromycin 2g PO stat
Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM in a single dose
Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM + Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days
Azithromycin 2g PO stat + Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 14 days

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with 60 kgs body weight presents with urethritis. Gram-staining of the purulent discharge is seen in the following image. What is the treatment of choice for this infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone 500mg IM + Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7 days

 

 

The Gram-stained image shows intracellular Gram-negative diplococci, consistent with Neisseria gonorrhoeae. This is a classic presentation of gonococcal urethritis. The optimal treatment must address both gonorrhea and potential Chlamydia trachomatis co-infection unless chlamydia is ruled out by NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test).

 

Correct Answer: C. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM + Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days

This is CDC-recommended first-line dual therapy (2021 guidelines) for treating uncomplicated gonococcal urethritis, particularly when Chlamydia infection has not been ruled out.

  • Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM: Covers Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Dose is increased to 1 gm if patient >150 kg.
  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 7 days: Preferred for Chlamydia trachomatis due to superior efficacy compared to azithromycin, especially for rectal chlamydial infections.

 

Why Not the Other Options?

A. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM + Azithromycin 2g PO stat

  • Azithromycin was previously part of the dual therapy.
  • However, CDC no longer recommends this combination due to:
    • Rising azithromycin resistance in Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
    • Inferior efficacy of azithromycin against rectal chlamydial infections.
  • Doxycycline has better tissue penetration and longer duration of action.

B. Ceftriaxone 500 mg IM in a single dose

  • Monotherapy, though effective for gonorrhea, is insufficient unless Chlamydia has been excluded by NAAT.
  • Does not address chlamydial co-infection, which is present in 15–40% of cases.

D. Azithromycin 2g PO stat + Doxycycline 100 mg BD for 14 days

  • Not guideline-recommended: No added benefit of giving both azithromycin and doxycycline together.
  • Duration of doxycycline here (14 days) exceeds the standard (7 days).

Why Doxycycline Over Azithromycin?

 

Kit-1 (Azithromycin + Cefixime) – Why Not Preferred?

  • Kit-1 (India): Contains Azithromycin 1g + Cefixime 800 mg.
  • Not the best choice due to:
    • Cefixime is oral and less effective than intramuscular ceftriaxone.
    • Azithromycin is not first-line anymore due to emerging resistance.
    • CDC now recommends ceftriaxone (IM) over cefixime due to superior pharmacokinetics and resistance profile.

Educational Objective

In the absence of NAAT results to exclude chlamydial infection, all patients with gonococcal urethritis should receive dual therapy with:

  • Ceftriaxone for N. gonorrhoeae, and
  • Doxycycline for C. trachomatis, as per CDC 2021 recommendations.

This ensures high efficacy, resistance prevention, and public health compliance.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 30, Page no 30.7

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 23 Page no 390

online resource

https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/gonorrhea-adults.htm

choices.text: Culture and sensitivity
Nucleic Acid Amplification Test
Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay
Microscopy showing inclusion bodies.

questions.text: Three weeks after an unprotected sexual encounter, a 46-year-old man experiences scanty mucoid discharge from his urethra. Which of the following diagnostic tests is advised?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nucleic acid amplification test

 

Option B:

Nucleic acid amplification test

 

Chlamydial urethritis is the likely diagnosis in this patient as it has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks, and the discharge characteristics are also in favour.

 

Only the Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT) is advised as a diagnostic test for Chlamydia. The samples used are:
 

  • Men - first void urine
  • Women - vaginal or endocervical swabs.

 

Serology, cell culture, and microscopy have no role in routine screening or diagnosis of non-gonococcal urethritis.
 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Culture and sensitivity
 

  • Although culture is a definitive method for pathogen identification and antibiotic sensitivity testing, it is less sensitive than NAAT for detecting Chlamydia and gonorrhea in urethral swabs.

 

Option C. Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA)
 

  • ELISA can be used for serological testing of various infections, but it is not the first line for direct detection of pathogens in cases of urethritis.

 

Option D. Microscopy showing inclusion bodies
 

  • Microscopy can be used to identify inclusion bodies characteristic of Chlamydia in cell cultures, but it is less sensitive and more labor-intensive than NAAT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the diagnosis of urethritis likely caused by a sexually transmitted infection, NAAT is recommended due to its superior sensitivity and specificity compared to other diagnostic tests.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.13

questions.text: The syndromic management of urethral discharge includes treatment of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria Gonorrhoea & Chlamydia Trachomatis

 

Option C:

Neisseria Gonorrhoea & Chlamydia Trachomatis

 

Syndromic management of urethral discharge includes treatment of Neisseria gonorrhoea & Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

 

Grey Kit/ Kit 1 used for Urethral discharge / Cervicitis / Anorectal discharge:
 

  • Tab Cefixime 800mg stat (gonococci)

  • Tab Azithromycin 1gm stat (chlamydia)

 

Not Doxycylcine 100mg BD x 7 days, to achieve COMPLIANCE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neisseria gonorrhoeae & herpes genitalis
 

  • While Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of urethral discharge, herpes genitalis, caused by the herpes simplex virus, typically presents with painful ulcers rather than urethral discharge.

 

Option B. Chlamydia trachomatis & herpes genitalis
 

  • Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of urethral discharge, but as stated above, herpes genitalis usually does not present primarily with discharge.

 

Option D. Syphilis & chancroid
 

  • Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, and chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, typically presents with genital ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The syndromic management of urethral discharge should include treatment for both Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis, which are the most common bacterial pathogens causing this condition.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 30 Page no 30.15

questions.text: Genital warts are most commonly caused by?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human Papillomavirus 6

 

Option D:

Human papillomavirus 6
 

  • Genital warts are most commonly caused by human papillomavirus (HPV-6 > HPV-11).
  • It is also called venereal warts or condyloma acuminata and has high infectivity. It is acquired most commonly after sexual contact but may also occur non-sexually.


 

  • Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.
  • The treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts with imiquimod cream via topical immunomodulation is approved.
  • An FDA-approved medication called imiquimod induces apoptosis in macrophages, monocytes, and dendritic cells by stimulating their Toll-like receptors 7 (TLR-7).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Human Papillomavirus-11
 

  • HPV-11 is also a cause of genital warts, along with HPV-6, and is included in the low-risk HPV types. But Genital warts are most commonly caused by HPV-6 > HPV-11

 

Option B. Human Papilloma Virus-2
 

  • HPV-2 is typically associated with common warts on the hands and feet, not with genital warts.


Option C. Human Papillomavirus-10
 

  • HPV-10 is not typically associated with genital warts. It is more commonly associated with other cutaneous warts.
     


Educational Objective:

 

  • HPV types 6 and 11 are the predominant causes of genital warts and are classified as low-risk HPV types due to their low oncogenic potential.
  • They are targeted by HPV vaccinations which aim to reduce the incidence of warts and other HPV-related conditions.


Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43​​​​​​​

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs)
Both A & B
Henderson Patterson bodies.

questions.text: A patient presents with following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

Option C:

Tzanck cells & MNGCs can be seen in Herpes lesions.

 

The provided image displays clusters of vesicles on an erythematous base, indicative of a possible diagnosis of genital herpes caused by Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.

 

Tzanck smear:

  • To perform a Tzanck smear, scrapings are obtained from the lesions, preferably from the base of the vesicles.
  • Smears are then prepared and stained with a 1% aqueous solution of O-toluidine blue for 15 seconds, which allows the visualization of acantholytic and multinucleated giant cells.
  • In Herpes infections, Tzanck smear examination may reveal the presence of Tzanck cells and multinucleated giant cells.

 

Below image depicts Acantholytic cells

 

 

Below image depicts multinucleated giant cells

 

 

  • Tzanck or Acantholytic cells are formed as a result of acantholysis, which is the breakdown of intercellular connections, like desmosomes.
  • This process leads to a reduction in cohesiveness among keratinocytes.

 

Acantholysis is classified as:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Henderson Patterson bodies:
 

  • These are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in cells infected with molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus.
  • This is not consistent with the lesion shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Herpes simplex virus infections, scrapings from lesions may show both Acantholytic / Tzanck cells and Multinucleate giant cells (MNGCs).

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 25 Page no 418

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 474-476

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 503

Online resources:

https://ijdvl.com/acantholysis-revisited-back-to-basics/

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with urethral discharge gram stain image below. which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria Gonorrhoea

 

Option C:

Neisseria Gonorrhoea
 

  • It is a gram-negative diplococcus bacterium that commonly presents with urethral discharge in infected individuals.
     
  • The gram stain of the discharge typically reveals gram-negative intracellular diplococci.
  • The presentation of acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge is characteristic of a gonococcal infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chlamydia trachomatis
 

  • This is also a common cause of urethritis, but it tends to produce a less pronounced, mucopurulent discharge.

 

Option B: Gardnerella vaginalis
 

  • This is associated with bacterial vaginosis and presents with a fishy odour and a Homogenous white adherent discharge It does not cause urethritis with purulent discharge.

 

Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis
 

  • This is a protozoan parasite causing trichomoniasis, which can result in urethritis, but it would not present with the gram-negative intracellular diplococci seen on gram stain.



 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When presented with a case of urethral discharge and gram-stain evidence of gram-negative intracellular diplococci, consider Neisseria gonorrhea as the most likely diagnosis.
  • This organism causes gonococcal urethritis, which is characterized by a profuse and purulent discharge and can lead to serious complications if left untreated.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 23 Page no 390

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.7

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1462

questions.text: Wife of a truck driver with multiple sexual partners presents to the Derma OPD with dysuria & vaginal discharge. On examination, cervical erosion (+). Which colour STD kit should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grey

 

Why the Correct Answer is option B) Grey Kit (Kit 1)

Clinical Summary:

  • Wife of a truck driver → High-risk sexual exposure
  • Symptoms → Vaginal discharge + dysuria
  • On per speculum examination → Cervical erosion seen

This clinical picture suggests cervicitis, not just vaginitis. Cervicitis is inflammation of the cervix, often caused by sexually transmitted infections (STIs) like Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Understanding Syndromic Management of STIs:

India’s National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) provides color-coded STI/RTI kits for syndromic treatment.

Key Point:

  • Grey Kit (Kit 1) is used for CERVICITIS – which can present with vaginal discharge, especially if cervical erosion is seen on exam.

Why Not the Other Kits?

Option A. Green Kit (Kit 2)

  • Used for vaginitis, including:
    • Bacterial vaginosis
    • Trichomoniasis
    • Vulvovaginal candidiasis
  • These conditions involve vaginal inflammation, not cervical pathology.
  • No cervical erosion is typically seen in pure vaginitis.

Option C. Red Kit (Kit 5)

  • Used for genital ulcer disease – herpetic ulcers.
  • No mention of ulcers in this case.

Option D. Yellow Kit (Kit 6)

  • Used for lower abdominal pain (PID), not applicable here.

Simple Rule to Remember:

Educational Objective:

  • Cervicitis often presents with vaginal discharge, but is distinguished by the presence of cervical erosion on speculum exam.
  • According to NACO guidelines, such cases are treated with the Grey Kit (Kit 1), which contains:
    • Cefixime (for gonorrhea) and
    • Azithromycin (for chlamydia)

 

Online resource:

National Technical Guidelines on Sexually Transmitted Infections and Reproductive Tract Infections 2024

https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National%20Technical%20Guidelines%20on%20STI%20and%20RTI_Final.pdf page 64

questions.text: A patient presents to you with multiple anogenital warts. The biopsy of these lesions showed squamous atypia. Which of the following HPV types are considered high risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HPV 18.

 

Option B:

HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
 

  • HPV 18 is considered a high-risk HPV type because it is associated with an increased risk of developing anogenital cancers, particularly cervical cancer.
  • High-risk HPV types can cause cellular changes that may progress to cancer if not treated.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HPV 2:
 

  • This type of HPV is considered low-risk and is typically associated with common warts, not anogenital warts or cancers.

 

Option C. HPV 6:
 

  • HPV 6 is also a low-risk type, commonly associated with the development of genital warts, but not with high-grade squamous atypia or cancer.

 

Option D. HPV 11:
 

  • Like HPV 6, HPV 11 is known to cause genital warts, but it is not associated with high-grade squamous lesions or malignancy.


 

 

 

Note - Gardasil-9 Nonavalent Vaccine - HPV-6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52 & 58. Protects against 6 cancers (Cervix, Vulva, Vagina, Anal Canal, Penis & Oral Cancers))+ Genital warts. 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the context of anogenital warts, HPV 18 is categorized as a high-risk type because of its association with anogenital carcinomas, especially cervical cancer.
  • In contrast, HPV types 6 and 11 are low-risk types commonly associated with benign anogenital warts and do not typically lead to cancer.
  • HPV 2 is typically associated with common skin warts and not anogenital lesions.
  • It is crucial for healthcare professionals to distinguish between high-risk and low-risk HPV types to provide appropriate patient counselling and management.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 440

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.44

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1393

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2727782/

questions.text: A women with multiple sexual partners came with complaints of lower abdominal pain, intermenstrual bleed, and dysuria. The causative organism would be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

 

Option C:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae
 

  • It can cause Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), which presents with lower abdominal pain, dysuria due to urethritis, and intermenstrual bleeding as a result of endometritis or cervicitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Candida
 

  • Candida species cause yeast infections, which typically present with pruritus, vaginal discharge that is often described as "cottage cheese-like," and no significant lower abdominal pain, intermenstrual bleeding, or dysuria.

 

Option B. HSV
 

  • Herpes Simplex Virus causes genital herpes, which is characterized by painful vesicular lesions, may cause dysuria if lesions are present in the urethra, but is not typically associated with lower abdominal pain or intermenstrual bleeding.

 

Option D. TB
 

  • Tuberculosis in the genital tract can cause Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, but it is less common and usually not associated with the acute presentation of symptoms like dysuria or intermenstrual bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common causative organism of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease, presenting with lower abdominal pain, intermenstrual bleeding, and dysuria, especially in a patient with multiple sexual partners.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 516

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1461

questions.text: Match the Diseases in Colum A with STI Kit colour in Colum B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Option A: 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correct match between the Diseases in Colum A with STI Kit colour in Colum B

 

    

Explanation:

 

1. Urethritis - b Grey –
 

  • Urethritis, which is inflammation of the urethra, typically presents with dysuria and discharge.

  • The grey color kit is often used for treatment protocols of urethritis, which includes antibiotics targeting common causative organisms like Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

 

2. Non-herpetic genital ulcers - c White / Blue –
 

  • Genital ulcers that are not caused by herpes simplex virus may be due to diseases like syphilis or chancroid.

  • The treatment for these conditions often involves antibiotics like penicillin or azithromycin, which may be represented by a white/blue colored kit.

 

3. Vaginal discharge - a Green –
 

  • The green kit is commonly associated with the treatment of vaginal discharge syndromes, which can be caused by bacterial vaginosis, trichomoniasis, or candidiasis.

  • Treatments usually include metronidazole, which are effective against these conditions.

 

4. Pelvic inflammatory disease - d Yellow –
 

  • The yellow kit is for managing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which requires broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover likely pathogens, including sexually transmitted ones.

 

Educational Objective:

Details of color coded STI/RTI kits -

 

Ref:

Online resource:

National Technical Guidelines on Sexually Transmitted Infections and Reproductive Tract Infections 2024

https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National%20Technical%20Guidelines%20on%20STI%20and%20RTI_Final.pdf  page 64

choices.text: Grams stain, Gram +ve organisms
Skin Biopsy, HP bodies
SSS, Acid fast Bacilli
Tzanck smear, Tzanck cells

questions.text: A college student came with painful grouped vesicles over genitalia. What will be next best investigation you want to perform and what could be the possible finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tzanck smear to detect Tzanck cells


Option D:

Tzanck smear to detect Tzanck cells.
 

  • The Tzanck smear is a test used to examine the cells from blistering skin conditions.
  • In the case of herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections, multinucleated giant cells and Tzanck cells, may be seen.
  • This test is quick and cost-effective, although not specific for HSV or VZV.

 

Some important findings on Tzanck smear are as follows:

 

 

The presence of acantholytic cells on a Tzanck smear, which is characterized by the loss of keratinocyte cell adhesion (acantholysis).

 

 

High power view of Tzanck cells. Note the perinuclear halo visible in the marked cell.

 

Image: Tzanck smear, showing multinucleated giant cells in center

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Tzanck_test.png
 

  • The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Gram stain to detect Gram-positive organisms
 

  • The Gram stain is used to classify bacteria as either Gram-positive or Gram-negative.
  • This test is not appropriate for the clinical scenario described, as the presentation is not suggestive of a bacterial infection.

 

Option B. Skin biopsy to detect HP bodies
 

  • HP (Henderson-Patterson) bodies are intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in molluscum contagiosum, which is not consistent with the presentation of painful genital vesicles.
  • A skin biopsy is more invasive and not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. SSS to detect Acid-fast bacilli
 

  • An SSS (Slit Skin Smear) test for acid-fast bacilli is used in the diagnosis of leprosy, neither of which typically present as painful grouped vesicles in the genital area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical presentation of painful grouped vesicles over the genitalia is most consistent with a herpes simplex virus infection, for which a Tzanck smear is a rapid diagnostic test that can demonstrate the presence of Tzanck cells, supporting the diagnosis.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 418

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 25.21

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1404

questions.text: A female married for 6 years and trying to conceive complaints of profuse non-foul smelling, non-itchy white discharge for 2 days. Her last menstrual period is 13-14 days back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Physiological

 

Option C:

 

Physiological
 

  • The most likely diagnosis for a female with profuse, non-foul smelling, non-itchy white discharge occurring mid-cycle is Physiological.
  • This type of discharge is typically associated with ovulation, which usually occurs around day 14 of a regular 28-day menstrual cycle.
  • The discharge is often clear to white, thin to viscous, and is considered normal if there is no associated itching, burning, or unpleasant odor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis
 

  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by a foul-smelling discharge that is typically gray in color.
  • It's also associated with a fishy odor, particularly after intercourse, which is not described in the presented case.

 

Option B. Candidiasis
 

  • Candidiasis, or a yeast infection, usually presents with a thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge that is accompanied by severe itching.
  • The lack of itching and the texture of the discharge make this diagnosis less likely.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis
 

  • Trichomoniasis typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green discharge with a foul odor and may cause itching and irritation.
  • The absence of these characteristics in the patient's description makes trichomoniasis an unlikely diagnosis.

​​​​​

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of a profuse, clear to white, non-foul smelling, and non-itchy discharge around the time of ovulation is most likely a physiological occurrence related to the normal menstrual cycle.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 784

questions.text: Match the Diseases in Colum A with STI Kit colour in Colum B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correct match between the Viral organisms / infections in Colum A with its Histopathological characteristic features in Colum B

 

A. 1-b, 2-c, 3-a

 

The correct matches:

 

 

1. Bubo is associated with STI Kit color b Black.

  • Inguinal Bubo under Genital Ulcer Disease Syndrome
  • LGV Proctitis under anorectal discharge syndrome
     

2. Herpetic genital ulcers are linked with STI Kit color c Red.

  •  

    • This reflects the association with herpes simplex virus infections, which often present as painful red ulcers.
       

3. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) has STI Kit color a Yellow.

  •  

    • PID is a spectrum of infections affecting the upper genital tract and can be caused by multiple organisms, including those causing STI
       

Educational Objective:

Details of color-coded RTI/STI kits - 

 

 

Ref:

Online resource:

National Technical Guidelines on Sexually Transmitted Infections and Reproductive Tract Infections 2024

https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National%20Technical%20Guidelines%20on%20STI%20and%20RTI_Final.pdf   page 64

questions.text: A 35-year-old male, who works as a truck driver, presents with a complaint of multiple painful ulcers on the glans penis, which have polycyclic margins. He also reports painful swelling in the groin area. Based on this clinical presentation, which of the following STI management kits should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Red

 

Option B: Red
 

  • This patient's symptoms are indicative of genital herpes, which is characterized by painful ulcers with polycyclic margins and can also cause painful lymphadenopathy.

  • The Red kit in syndromic management is used for the treatment of genital herpes, as it typically includes antiviral therapy suitable for herpes simplex virus, the causative agent of herpetic genital ulcers.

 

KIT 5

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blue
 

  • The Blue kit is used for the management of non-herpetic genital ulcers, not for Herpetic genital ulcers.

 

Option C. White
 

  • The White kit is typically used for the management of non-herpetic genital ulcers, not for Herpetic genital ulcers.

 

Option D. Yellow
 

  • The Yellow kit is generally used for Pelvic Inflammatory disease in females and does not apply to the patient's presentation of genital ulcers and lymphadenopathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Painful genital ulcers with polycyclic margins and painful lymphadenopathy are consistent with genital herpes, which is treated with the Red kit according to syndromic management guidelines.

 

Ref:

Online resource:

National Technical Guidelines on Sexually Transmitted Infections and Reproductive Tract Infections 2024

https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National%20Technical%20Guidelines%20on%20STI%20and%20RTI_Final.pdf   page 64

choices.text: On wet mount multiple WBCs are visible

questions.text: A female presented with malodorous white discharge. She didn't complain of any itching. Adding KOH produced fishy odour. Which of the following is TRUE about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) pH of vagina is >4.5

 

Option C:

pH of vagina is >4.5.

 

  • The patient's symptoms of malodorous white discharge without itching and the presence of a fishy odor upon the addition of KOH suggest bacterial vaginosis (BV).
  • BV is characterized by an elevated vaginal pH greater than 4.5, which is basic compared to the normal acidic environment of the vagina.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cervical petechiae are visible.
 

  • Cervical petechiae, also known as strawberry cervix, are indicative of trichomoniasis, not bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option B. On wet mount multiple WBCs are visible
 

  • While WBCs may be present in various vaginal infections, the presence of multiple WBCs on a wet mount is more characteristic of infections such as trichomoniasis or vulvovaginal candidiasis, not specifically bacterial vaginosis.

 

Option D. This is an STD
 

  • Bacterial vaginosis is not classified as an STD.
  • It is associated with an imbalance of the vaginal flora and can be sexually associated but is not considered a traditional sexually transmitted infection.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnostic criteria for bacterial vaginosis, include the absence of itching and a vaginal pH >4.5.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 401, 784

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 32.64

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1256

choices.text: Doxycycline is the treatment of choice
Gram negative Diplococci are seen on smear
His testes can also get involved

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with profuse purulent urethral discharge along with intense burning sensation as shown in the picture. He had moderate grade fever. Which of the following is TRUE regarding his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gram negative Diplococci are seen on smear

 

  • This is indicative of gonococcal urethritis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The presence of profuse purulent discharge and a burning sensation during urination are classic symptoms. The identification of Gram-negative diplococci in urethral smears is a hallmark diagnostic feature.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Doxycycline is the treatment of choice
 

  • Doxycycline is commonly used for chlamydial infections, not gonococcal infections. The current recommended treatment for gonorrhoea is ceftriaxone.

 

Option C. His testes can also get involved:
 

  • Gonococcal infection can lead to epididymitis, but spares testes, and also the presence of Gram-negative diplococci on a smear is more directly related to the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Incubation period is 10 days:
 

  • The incubation period for gonorrhea is typically shorter, ranging from 2 to 5 days. While it can be longer, a 10-day incubation period is more suggestive for Non gonococcal urethritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gonococcal urethritis in a male patient, characterized by profuse purulent urethral discharge and a burning sensation during urination, with diagnosis confirmed by the presence of Gram-negative diplococci on urethral smear.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 75

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 30.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1460

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with vaginal discharge and itching. Her male partner has no symptoms. Which of the following conditions necessitates treatment of the male partner?
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Trichomoniasis

 

Option D:

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. 
  • It is recommended that both partners be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection, even if the male partner is asymptomatic. 
  • Treatment typically includes a course of metronidazole or tinidazole.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A (Bacterial vaginosis):  

  • This is an overgrowth of normal vaginal flora and is not considered a sexually transmitted infection.
  • Routine treatment of the male partner is not recommended. 

 

Option B (Herpes genitalis): 

  • This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the herpes simplex virus. While sexual partners should be informed and preventive measures should be taken to avoid transmission, especially during outbreaks, treatment of the male partner is not required unless he shows symptoms.

Option C (Candidiasis): 

  • This is a yeast infection caused by Candida species. It is not classified as a sexually transmitted infection, and treatment of the male partner is not typically necessary unless he shows symptoms of infection (e.g., balanitis).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection that requires the treatment of both the female patient and her male partner to prevent reinfection.
  • Bacterial vaginosis and candidiasis are not considered sexually transmitted, and routine treatment of the male partner is not necessary.  
  • Herpes genitalis requires preventive measures rather than treatment of an asymptomatic partner.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 33, Page no’s 33.35 and 33.36

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Anogenital warts in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cryosurgery.

 

Option B:

Cryosurgery:
 

  • This is the correct answer. Cryosurgery, which involves freezing the warts with liquid nitrogen, is considered safe and effective for treating anogenital warts during pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Podophyllin application:
 

  • This is not the treatment of choice in pregnancy due to its potential toxicity to the fetus. Podophyllin is contraindicated during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Application of Imiquimod:
 

  • Imiquimod is not the preferred treatment during pregnancy as its safety for the fetus has not been established.

 

Option D. Application of 5 FU (5-fluorouracil):
 

  • 5-fluorouracil is not recommended during pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cryosurgery is the treatment of choice for anogenital warts in pregnancy because it is safe and effective, with minimal risk to the fetus.

 

Ref:

Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 438

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 112.29

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1397
